security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill with no executable code. All flagged patterns are false positives from markdown documentation content. The skill provides instructions for using markdownlint-cli2, a legitimate open-source tool. No security concerns identified.

content.user_title: Lint and fix markdown formatting automatically
content.value_statement: Markdown files often contain style inconsistencies that reduce readability. This skill uses markdownlint-cli2 to automatically detect and fix common formatting problems while identifying issues that need human judgment.
actual_capabilities: Check markdown files for style violations using markdownlint-cli2
Automatically fix 70-90% of formatting issues with --fix flag
Validate documents against configurable markdown rules
Identify issues requiring manual judgment like document hierarchy
Apply consistent markdown styling across multiple files
Generate custom rule configurations for project needs
limitations: Requires markdownlint-cli2 to be installed on the system
Cannot automatically fix structural issues like multiple H1 headers
Line length and header hierarchy require human judgment to resolve
Does not handle intentional rule violations in code examples

use_cases.title: Standardize documentation style
use_cases.description: Ensure all project documentation follows consistent markdown conventions and style rules across dozens of files.

use_cases.title: Clean up README files
use_cases.description: Validate and fix markdown formatting in README files, contribution guides, and documentation before releases.

use_cases.title: Improve article readability
use_cases.description: Clean up markdown formatting in blog posts and educational content to meet publication standards.

output_examples.input: Check and fix all markdown issues in my README.md file
output: - MD025: Converted 2 duplicate H1 headers to H2 level
- MD036: Changed bold emphasis to proper H2 header
- MD013: Wrapped long line at natural punctuation break
Final verification: 0 errors - document is fully compliant

output_examples.input: Lint all markdown files in the docs folder
output: Results: 8 files clean, 4 files need manual review
Common issues: Multiple H1 headers and line length violations

best_practices: Always run auto-fix first to handle mechanical issues before manual review
Create a project-specific markdownlint config file to define consistent rules
Verify final output shows zero errors before considering the work complete
anti_patterns: Manually fixing all issues without using auto-fix (wastes time on mechanical problems)
Disabling all rules that show errors instead of understanding and fixing issues
Skipping final verification step and assuming auto-fix resolved everything

faq.question: What markdown rules does this skill check?
faq.answer: Supports all markdownlint rules including header levels, list formatting, trailing spaces, line length, blank lines, and code block formatting.

faq.question: Can I customize which rules are enforced?
faq.answer: Yes. Create a .markdownlint.json file to enable, disable, or configure rules like line length thresholds and HTML allowances.

faq.question: Does auto-fix modify my original files?
faq.answer: Yes. The --fix flag modifies files in place. Use version control or work on copies to preserve originals.

faq.question: Why do some errors remain after auto-fix?
faq.answer: Auto-fix handles mechanical issues only. Structural problems like document hierarchy and line break placement require human judgment.

faq.question: What files does this skill access?
faq.answer: Only markdown files you explicitly specify. No system files, credentials, or sensitive data are accessed.

faq.question: How does this compare to other formatters?
faq.answer: Uses markdownlint-cli2 which follows comprehensive linting rules with detailed error codes, more thorough than basic formatters.
